rev.comment: "proprietary" is ambiguous and should be avoided, replaced with "closed-source"
rev.diff:
Line 23: Line 23:
'''Google Chrome''' is a [[web browser]] developed by [[Google]] that uses the [[WebKit]] [[layout engine]] and [[application framework]]. It was first released as a [[beta version]] for [[Microsoft Windows]] on 2 September 2008, and the public stable release was on 11 December 2008. The name is derived from the [[graphical user interface]] frame, or "[[User interface chrome|chrome]]", of web browsers. {{asof|2010|03}}, Chrome was the third most widely used browser, with 6.13% of worldwide [[usage share of web browsers]], according to [[Net Applications]].<ref name="Browser Market Share">{{cite web |url=http://marketshare.hitslink.com/browser-market-share.aspx?qprid=0 |title=Browser Market Share |date=2010-04-01 |publisher=Net Applications |accessdate=2010-04-01}}</ref>
'''Google Chrome''' is a [[web browser]] developed by [[Google]] that uses the [[WebKit]] [[layout engine]] and [[application framework]]. It was first released as a [[beta version]] for [[Microsoft Windows]] on 2 September 2008, and the public stable release was on 11 December 2008. The name is derived from the [[graphical user interface]] frame, or "[[User interface chrome|chrome]]", of web browsers. {{asof|2010|03}}, Chrome was the third most widely used browser, with 6.13% of worldwide [[usage share of web browsers]], according to [[Net Applications]].<ref name="Browser Market Share">{{cite web |url=http://marketshare.hitslink.com/browser-market-share.aspx?qprid=0 |title=Browser Market Share |date=2010-04-01 |publisher=Net Applications |accessdate=2010-04-01}}</ref>
â
In September 2008, Google released a large portion of Chrome's source code, including its [[V8 (JavaScript engine)|V8 JavaScript engine]], as an [[open source]] project entitled [[Chromium (web browser)|Chromium]].<ref>[http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2008/09/google-unveils-chrome-source-code-and-linux-port.ars Google unveils Chrome source code and Linux port], Ars Technica</ref><ref>"Google Chrome is built with open source code from Chromium." Retrieved from: http://dev.chromium.org/developers/how-tos/getting-started.</ref> This move enabled third-party developers to study the underlying source code and help port the browser to Mac OS X and Linux. A Google spokesperson also expressed hope that other browsers would adopt V8 to help web applications.<ref>''"During a press briefing today, Google expressed hope that other browsers..."'', Retrieved from: [http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2008/09/google-unveils-chrome-source-code-and-linux-port.ars Google unveils Chrome source code and Linux port], Ars Technica</ref> The Google-authored portion of Chromium is released under the permissive [[BSD license]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Home (Chromium Developer Documentation)|url=http://dev.chromium.org/Home|accessdate=2009-05-05|publisher=dev.chromium.org|year=2009|work=Chromium Developer Documentation}}</ref> which allows portions to be incorporated into both open source and proprietary software programs.<ref>''"Google has made the Chrome source available under a permissive BSD license so that..."'', Retrieved from: [http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2008/09/google-unveils-chrome-source-code-and-linux-port.ars Google unveils Chrome source code and Linux port], Ars Technica</ref> Other portions of the source code are subject to a variety of open-source licenses.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://code.google.com/chromium/terms.html |title=Chromium Terms and Conditions |date=2008-09-02|accessdate=2008-09-03 |work=[[Google Code]]}}</ref> Chromium implements the same feature set as Chrome, but lacks automatic updates and Google branding, most notably it has a blue-colored logo in place of the multicolored Google logo.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://weblog.infoworld.com/fatalexception/archives/2008/09/building_google.html|title=Building Google Chrome: A first look |last=McAllister |first=Neil |date=2008-09-11 |work=Fatal Exception |publisher=InfoWorld |accessdate=2008-09-16 |quote=As the name suggests, Chromium is a rawer, less polished version of Chrome. The UI is mostly identical, with only a few very minor visual differences...The most readily evident difference is the logo, which sheds the Google colors in favor of a subdued blue design}}</ref>
+
In September 2008, Google released a large portion of Chrome's source code, including its [[V8 (JavaScript engine)|V8 JavaScript engine]], as an [[open source]] project entitled [[Chromium (web browser)|Chromium]].<ref>[http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2008/09/google-unveils-chrome-source-code-and-linux-port.ars Google unveils Chrome source code and Linux port], Ars Technica</ref><ref>"Google Chrome is built with open source code from Chromium." Retrieved from: http://dev.chromium.org/developers/how-tos/getting-started.</ref> This move enabled third-party developers to study the underlying source code and help port the browser to Mac OS X and Linux. A Google spokesperson also expressed hope that other browsers would adopt V8 to help web applications.<ref>''"During a press briefing today, Google expressed hope that other browsers..."'', Retrieved from: [http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2008/09/google-unveils-chrome-source-code-and-linux-port.ars Google unveils Chrome source code and Linux port], Ars Technica</ref> The Google-authored portion of Chromium is released under the permissive [[BSD license]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Home (Chromium Developer Documentation)|url=http://dev.chromium.org/Home|accessdate=2009-05-05|publisher=dev.chromium.org|year=2009|work=Chromium Developer Documentation}}</ref> which allows portions to be incorporated into both open source and closed-source software programs.<ref>''"Google has made the Chrome source available under a permissive BSD license so that..."'', Retrieved from: [http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2008/09/google-unveils-chrome-source-code-and-linux-port.ars Google unveils Chrome source code and Linux port], Ars Technica</ref> Other portions of the source code are subject to a variety of open-source licenses.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://code.google.com/chromium/terms.html |title=Chromium Terms and Conditions |date=2008-09-02|accessdate=2008-09-03 |work=[[Google Code]]}}</ref> Chromium implements the same feature set as Chrome, but lacks automatic updates and Google branding, most notably it has a blue-colored logo in place of the multicolored Google logo.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://weblog.infoworld.com/fatalexception/archives/2008/09/building_google.html|title=Building Google Chrome: A first look |last=McAllister |first=Neil |date=2008-09-11 |work=Fatal Exception |publisher=InfoWorld |accessdate=2008-09-16 |quote=As the name suggests, Chromium is a rawer, less polished version of Chrome. The UI is mostly identical, with only a few very minor visual differences...The most readily evident difference is the logo, which sheds the Google colors in favor of a subdued blue design}}</ref>
